prevention.title: Prevention
prevention.description: Install smoke alarms on every floor and in key areas like bedrooms and kitchens. Test them monthly and replace batteries annually. Keep fire extinguishers accessible and learn how to use them. Create and practice a home fire escape plan with all household members.

detection.title: Early Fire Detection
detection.description: Know the signs of fire: visible flames, smoke, burning smell, unusual warmth, crackling sounds, or smoke detector alarms. Early detection saves lives and property.

assess.title: Assess the Fire Situation
assess.description: Quickly determine the size, location, and type of fire (electrical, grease, paper/wood, chemical). Small, contained fires may be manageable, but prepare to evacuate immediately if the fire is spreading rapidly.

alarm.title: Activate the Alarm and Call Emergency Services
alarm.description: Pull the fire alarm if in a public building. Call emergency services immediately (911 in US, 101 in Mongolia). Give your exact location and details about the fire. Never assume someone else has called.

evacuation.title: Evacuation Priorities
evacuation.description: People first, possessions second. Alert everyone in the building. Help those who need assistance. Never re-enter a burning building for belongings.

safeescape.title: Safe Evacuation Techniques
safeescape.description: Stay low to avoid smoke inhalation (crawl if necessary). Test doors before opening - use the back of your hand to feel for heat. If the door is hot, find another exit route. Close doors behind you to slow fire spread. Use stairs, never elevators.

trapped.title: If Trapped in a Room
trapped.description: Block smoke from entering by placing wet towels or clothing under doors. Signal for help from windows. If possible, call emergency services to report your exact location. Cover your mouth and nose with a damp cloth.

assess.title: Check Responsiveness
assess.description: Tap the person's shoulders and shout 'Are you okay?' If no response, continue with CPR.

call.title: Call for Help
call.description: Call emergency services immediately and get an AED if available.

position.title: Position the Person
position.description: Place the person on their back on a firm, flat surface. Tilt the head back slightly and lift the chin.

compressions.title: Begin Chest Compressions
compressions.description: Place the heel of your hand on the center of the chest between the nipples. Push hard and fast at least 2 inches deep at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

rescue.title: Give Rescue Breaths
rescue.description: After 30 compressions, give 2 rescue breaths. Tilt head back, lift chin, pinch nose closed, and give 2 breaths.

continue.title: Continue CPR
continue.description: Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until emergency services arrive or the person starts breathing normally.

recognize.title: Recognize Choking
recognize.description: Universal choking sign: hands on throat. Person cannot speak, cough, or breathe.

encourage.title: Encourage Coughing
encourage.description: If person can still cough, encourage them to continue coughing to expel the object.

backblows.title: Give Back Blows
backblows.description: 5 forceful blows between shoulder blades with heel of hand. Lean person forward.

heimlich.title: Heimlich Maneuver
heimlich.description: From behind, wrap around waist. Place fist above navel, grasp with other hand, give 5 quick upward thrusts.

infant.title: For Infants
infant.description: 5 back blows, then 5 chest thrusts. Never use Heimlich maneuver on infants under 1 year.

unconscious.title: If Unconscious
unconscious.description: Begin CPR. Before each rescue breath, check mouth for visible objects and remove only if visible.

assess.title: Assess Bleeding
assess.description: Identify severity of bleeding and source. For severe bleeding, apply pressure immediately.

pressure.title: Direct Pressure
pressure.description: Press clean cloth or bandage firmly on wound. Maintain constant, firm pressure.

elevate.title: Elevate
elevate.description: If possible and no fracture suspected, raise bleeding limb above heart level.

pressure_points.title: Use Pressure Points
pressure_points.description: For persistent bleeding, apply pressure on arteries between wound and heart.

tourniquet.title: Tourniquet as Last Resort
tourniquet.description: Only for life-threatening bleeding. Apply 2-4 inches above wound. Record time of application.

shock.title: Monitor for Shock
shock.description: Watch for shock signs: pale skin, rapid pulse, weakness. Lay person down and keep warm.

treatment.title: Treatment Guidelines
treatment.description: Comprehensive treatment guidelines for various medical conditions.
treatment.comingSoonDesc: We are working on adding detailed treatment guidelines. Please check back later.

medications.subtitle: Access detailed information about 5000+ medications including dosages, side effects, interactions, and safety warnings.

medications.tryDifferentSearch: Try adjusting your search terms or category filter
medications.disclaimerText: This information is for educational purposes only and should not replace professional medical advice. Always consult with your healthcare provider before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. In case of emergency, contact your local emergency services immediately.

symptoms.head: Head
symptoms.disclaimer: This tool provides general guidance only. Always consult healthcare professionals for proper diagnosis.
symptoms.noSymptoms: Please select at least one symptom to continue.
symptoms.criticalWarning: CRITICAL: If experiencing severe symptoms, call emergency services immediately!

damageAssessment.disclaimer: This AI assessment provides an initial evaluation only and should not replace professional medical or emergency services judgment. In case of serious injury, seek professional help immediately.

medicalImaging.title: Medical Imaging Analysis

medicalImaging.uploadFirst: Upload or capture an image to get started

medicalImaging.welcomeMessage: Hello! I'm your medical imaging assistant. I can help analyze X-rays, MRIs, and other medical images. Upload an image or ask me questions about medical imaging.
medicalImaging.apiKeyRequired: An API key is required for medical imaging analysis
medicalImaging.disclaimer: This AI analysis is for informational purposes only and does not replace professional medical diagnosis. Always consult with a qualified healthcare provider for proper interpretation of medical images and treatment decisions.

medicationAdvisor.title: Medication Advisor

medicationAdvisor.disclaimer: Clinical Decision Support Disclaimer: This tool provides recommendations based on established clinical guidelines and should be used as a reference only. All treatment decisions must be made by qualified healthcare providers based on individual patient assessment. This system does not replace clinical judgment.

compliance.hipaaText: This system contains Protected Health Information (PHI). Access is monitored and logged. Unauthorized access or disclosure is prohibited by law.
compliance.fdaText: Medication information provided is for educational purposes. Always verify dosing with current FDA labeling and consult clinical pharmacists for patient-specific recommendations.
compliance.medicalText: This information is not intended to replace professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified healthcare provider.
compliance.emergencyText: In case of medical emergency, call emergency services immediately. Do not rely on this application for emergency care decisions.
compliance.dataText: Patient data is encrypted and stored securely in compliance with healthcare regulations.
compliance.auditText: All access to patient records is logged for security and compliance purposes.

signup.selectTypeDescription: Choose the type of account that best fits your needs

step1.title: Check Responsiveness
step1.description: Tap shoulders firmly and shout 'Are you okay?' Look for normal breathing for no more than 10 seconds. If unresponsive and not breathing normally, begin CPR.
step1.tip3: Act quickly - brain damage starts in 4-6 minutes

step2.title: Call for Help
step2.description: Call emergency services immediately or have someone else do it. Request an AED if available. If alone with phone, put on speaker. Don't leave to get help.

step3.title: Position Person
step3.description: Place on firm, flat surface. Tilt head back slightly by lifting chin. Place heel of one hand on center of chest between nipples. Place other hand on top, interlacing fingers.
step3.tip2: Center of chest, not too high

step4.title: Begin Chest Compressions
step4.description: Push hard and fast at least 2 inches deep. Allow complete chest recoil between compressions. Compress at 100-120 per minute. Count out loud.
step4.tip2: Let chest come back up completely

step5.title: Provide Rescue Breaths (if trained)
step5.description: After 30 compressions, tilt head back, lift chin, pinch nose. Cover mouth completely and give 2 breaths (1 second each). Watch for chest rise.
step5.tip3: Chest should rise with each breath

step6.title: Continue Until Help Arrives
step6.description: Don't stop until EMS arrives, person starts breathing normally, or you become exhausted. Use AED immediately when available and follow voice prompts.
step6.tip2: AED will guide you through process

step1.title: Balance - Check for Loss of Coordination
step1.description: Ask about sudden balance loss, dizziness, or coordination problems. Look for trouble walking, loss of coordination, unexplained falls.
step1.tip1: May be only sign of posterior stroke

step2.title: Eyes - Check for Vision Loss
step2.description: Ask about sudden vision loss, double vision, or visual field cuts. Have them track your finger. Test peripheral vision.

step3.title: Face - Check for Facial Drooping
step3.description: Ask person to smile broadly showing teeth. Look for uneven/lopsided smile, facial drooping, or asymmetric movement.

step4.title: Arms - Check for Weakness
step4.description: Ask to raise both arms overhead for 10 seconds with palms up, eyes closed. Look for arm drift, inability to lift one arm, or weakness.

step5.title: Speech - Check for Speech Problems
step5.description: Ask to repeat a simple phrase. Listen for slurred speech, wrong words, or inability to understand.

step6.title: Time - Call Emergency Services Immediately
step6.description: If ANY signs present, note exact time symptoms started and call emergency services. Tell dispatcher 'possible stroke' and time of onset. Time is brain.
step6.tip3: Transport to stroke center if available

step1.title: Assess the Situation
step1.description: Look for universal choking sign (hands clutching throat). Ask 'Are you choking?' If person can cough, speak, or breathe, encourage coughing.
step1.tip1: Coughing means some air is moving

step2.title: Position for Back Blows
step2.description: Stand to side and slightly behind. Support chest with one hand, lean them forward so object falls out rather than down throat.

step3.title: Give 5 Sharp Back Blows
step3.description: Using heel of hand, give up to 5 sharp blows between shoulder blades. Each blow separate and distinct. Check mouth after each blow.

step4.title: Perform 5 Abdominal Thrusts
step4.description: Stand behind person. Place fist above navel, below ribs. Grasp with other hand, give 5 quick upward/inward thrusts.

step5.title: Continue Alternating Techniques
step5.description: Keep alternating 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until object expelled, person can breathe/speak, or becomes unconscious.

step6.title: If Person Becomes Unconscious
step6.description: Lower to ground, call emergency services if not done. Begin CPR with chest compressions. Before rescue breaths, check mouth and remove visible objects only.
step6.tip2: Check mouth before each breath cycle
step6.tip3: Don't stop compressions to search for object

step1.title: Scene Safety and Protection
step1.description: Assess scene for ongoing dangers. Wear gloves or create barrier with plastic bags/cloth. Your safety first - you can't help if you become injured.

step2.title: Call Emergency Services for Severe Bleeding
step2.description: Call immediately for life-threatening bleeding. Say 'severe bleeding/hemorrhage' and location. Request blood products and trauma team for massive bleeding.
step2.tip3: Designate someone else to call if possible

step3.title: Apply Direct Pressure
step3.description: Place clean cloth/gauze directly on wound. Press firmly with both hands if needed. Don't peek or lift to check - maintain constant pressure.

step4.title: Elevate if Possible
step4.description: If no fracture suspected, raise bleeding area above heart level. Support while maintaining pressure. Don't elevate if spinal injuries suspected.
step4.tip1: Works best for arms and legs

step5.title: Pressure Points if Needed
step5.description: If direct pressure fails, apply pressure to arterial points between wound and heart. Arm wounds: brachial artery. Leg wounds: femoral artery in groin.
step5.tip1: Use only if direct pressure insufficient

step6.title: Tourniquet for Life-Threatening Limb Bleeding
step6.description: For severe limb bleeding not controlled by pressure, apply tourniquet 2-3 inches above wound. Tighten until bleeding stops. Write time on tourniquet.

step1.title: Recognize Heart Attack Symptoms
step1.description: Classic: chest pain/pressure, shortness of breath, nausea, sweating, pain to arms/jaw/back. Women may have atypical symptoms: fatigue, indigestion, back pain.

step2.title: Call Emergency Services - Don't Drive
step2.description: Call immediately, don't drive to hospital. Say 'possible heart attack' with location. EMS can start treatment and bypass ER.

step3.title: Give Aspirin if Safe
step3.description: Give 325mg aspirin to chew if conscious, not allergic, no bleeding disorders. Chewing is faster than swallowing. Don't delay calling for aspirin.

step4.title: Position for Comfort
step4.description: Help sit upright in chair or half-sitting with pillows - reduces heart workload. Loosen tight clothing. Keep calm and still.

step5.title: Monitor and Reassure
step5.description: Stay with person until help arrives. Monitor breathing and consciousness. Be prepared to perform CPR if they become unresponsive.

step1.title: Recognize Anaphylaxis Signs
step1.description: Look for: hives/swelling, difficulty breathing, throat tightness, rapid pulse, dizziness, nausea. Symptoms develop within minutes of exposure.

step2.title: Call Emergency Services Immediately
step2.description: Call emergency services stating 'severe allergic reaction/anaphylaxis'. This is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate treatment.
step2.tip2: Don't wait to see if symptoms improve

step3.title: Use Epinephrine Auto-Injector
step3.description: If available, use epinephrine auto-injector immediately. Inject into outer thigh through clothing if necessary. Hold for 10 seconds.
step3.tip3: A second dose may be needed

step4.title: Position Appropriately
step4.description: If breathing difficulty: sit upright. If feeling faint: lie down with legs elevated. If vomiting or pregnant: lie on side.
step4.tip2: Don't let them stand or walk

step5.title: Monitor for Biphasic Reaction
step5.description: Symptoms can return hours after initial reaction. Stay with person and monitor. Second dose of epinephrine may be needed.

treatment.infoNote: These guidelines are simplified for quick reference. Treatment decisions should consider individual patient factors, local protocols, and current best practices.
treatment.noResults: No treatment guidelines found matching your search criteria.
treatment.disclaimerText: This information is provided for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified healthcare provider with any questions regarding a medical condition.

symptoms.criticalWarning: You've selected one or more symptoms that may indicate a medical emergency. Please consider calling emergency services (103) immediately.
symptoms.disclaimer: Disclaimer: This is not a medical diagnosis. Always consult with a healthcare professional for proper medical advice.
symptoms.noResults: No matching conditions found based on your symptoms.
symptoms.noResultsAdvice: This doesn't mean you're not experiencing a medical issue. If you're concerned, please consult a healthcare professional.
symptoms.emergencyCall: If you are experiencing a medical emergency, please call 103 (Mongolia) immediately.

maintenance.scheduleDescription: Automated maintenance tasks to keep emergency systems updated and reliable
maintenance.automatedDescription: The system automatically performs critical maintenance tasks including database updates, map synchronization, and AI model improvements. Manual intervention is only required for high-priority items or when automatic processes detect issues.
